awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Social Support and Stress Among Religious Migrants
awd_abstract_narration:
Migration is a stressful process, with unique stressors emerging before, during, and after migration. For religious migrants, people in their congregations are important sources of support. However, providing the support necessary to cope with the stressors of migration may be complicated if what constitutes support differs between the giver and the receiver. The purpose of this dissertation research is to compare religious migrant and non-migrant understandings of social support and whether their adherence to local expectations of social support is associated with stress (perceived stress as well as hormonal measures). By approaching migration from both a biological and a cultural perspective, this project provides clarity with respect to the impact of chronic stressors among migrants. It also broadens the participation of women in STEM, as it provides training for a woman graduate student in lab and field work. The findings of this research will be disseminated broadly to participant communities and academic and non-academic audiences.

The researcher applies a biocultural approach to understandings of migrant religion and post-national theory to answer the questions: 1. Do migrants and non-migrants of the same religion understand social support the same way? 2. In what ways are migrant understandings of social support similar to or different from those currently described in scientific scholarship? 3. How does secular and non-secular education influence how migrants and non-migrants understand social support? 4. Is the degree to which a migrant or non-migrant gives and receives culturally appropriate social support associated with stress (perceived stress as well as hormonal measures of stress)? To answer these questions, the researcher employs methods that measure the presence of shared cultural norms (cultural consensus) as well as individual adherence to these norms (cultural consonance). Cortisol, a hormone associated with stress and accessible in hair, is used to measure biological stress. The combination of these theoretical approaches and methods provides a novel approach to understanding the migrant experience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated whether immigrants and non-immigrants in a single religious community have a shared understanding of what it means to give and receive support or help. The researchers found that among American non-immigrants and Latinx immigrants in two congregations of the same religion in a close geographical area agree on what actions they considered to be helpful and important to give and receive from their fellow religious adherents. They also agree on the general purpose of these various types of support as well as which groups of individuals in their congregations are most responsible for providing this type of assistance.

In interviews, both immigrants and non-immigrants share similar beliefs about the role of help/support in their spiritual development (particularly a giver of support's relationship with divine beings, such as Jesus Christ). They also are alike in describing the importance of relationships in providing support- both groups highlight how these religious individuals provide support through naturally occurring relationships, where individuals just "click" and become friends as well as relationships that they build in order to know how to help or support that individual.

When looking at how support or help is associated with health, the researchers focused on stress and depression levels (both those that participants in the researcher reported themselves, as well as biological measurements of hormones that rise and fall with stressful events that someone experiences). The researchers found that immigrants and non-immigrants have different experiences with stress and depression when compared with the help they feel they can give and receive in their religious congregations. For non-immigrants, the more they feel they can receive appropriate types of help in their congregations, the lower their depression levels are. Immigrants, however, did not follow this same pattern. More research is needed to understand the experience immigrants have receiving support and how that relates to their health. However, through interviewing immigrants, researchers suspect that immigrants have a different experience because they experience racism and anti-immigrant sentiments in their communities, including in their religious congregations.

This study also found that for immigrants and non-immigrants, as levels of confidence in the ability to receive support from their religious congregation went up, the level of the stress hormone cortisol in their hair also went up. This is a surprising finding that will require more research to understand.

The findings of this research are particularly useful for other researchers seeking to understand the experience immigrants have in religious communities in the United States, as well as patterns in immigrant health. This project included measurements of stress (particularly cortisol in hair) which is not common in anthropological research. This work will thus help other anthropologists as well as non-anthropologists to think about new ways to measure stress among immigrants.

This research also is useful to leaders and members of religious communities, particularly religious communities in which immigrants are present. The findings of this research have been influential in helping local congregational leadership recognize the influence they hold in either contributing to the unity or marginalization of the immigrant members of their congregations. Based on the findings of this research, some actionable ways to encourage unity between immigrant and non-immigrant congregation members include:

  1. Encouraging religious leaders to seek out cultural awareness training
  2. Leadership can also actively find positions or roles that immigrant congregants can fill.
  3. Leadership can find ways (that will likely be specific to their own congregations) to create bridges between immigrant and non-immigrant members. Bridge-building activities may include cultural celebrations or service projects with immigrant and non-immigrants working alongside one another.

Even small, occasional adjustments to encourage interaction between culturally diverse congregants can increase unity and provide a much better experience for immigrant members.

This project also had direct impacts on students and members of the religious community that participated in this research. It contributed to multiple women doctoral students learning key laboratory skills that will benefit them in their future STEM-oriented careers. Additionally, during the research period, the student researcher on this project contributed to the congregations participating in this research in numerous ways, including teaching English classes to Spanish speakers, being a mentor and teacher to teenage girls in both congregations, and assisting in community service projects sponsored by the congregations.
